Introduction

The National Patient Safety Agency (NPSA) highlighted a significant number of incidents where delays in patient management had occurred due to clinical teams not having received, read or acted upon the results of imaging examinations.
According to the Royal College of Radiologists (“standards for the communication of critical, urgent and unexpected significant radiological findings” 2016):
It is the responsibility of the radiologist (or reporting practitioner) to produce reports as quickly and efficiently as possible.
Reports should be timely, clear and precise and the urgency for action should be documented in the content of the report.
Once the report is complete / authorised it must be available to the referring clinician in a timely manner.
It is the responsibility of the requesting clinician and/or their clinical team to read and act upon the result of every investigation they generate.
There should be safety nets established for critical and significant unexpected findings.
Imaging departments must make it clear to patients how and when they should expect to receive the results of a diagnostic test.
Scope
The purpose of this document is to:
Ensure there is standardised practice for all staff responsible for diagnostic reporting across MSE.

Ensure that the radiological imaging reports are communicated to, and received by, the appropriate registered health professional and, where necessary, action is taken in a manner appropriate to their clinical urgency
Ensure there are clear guidelines for both the diagnostic reporting staff and the referring clinician as to what constitutes critical or urgent unexpected findings.

Ensure that the referrer is aware of their responsibility for reading the result of every diagnostic examination they generate and acting appropriately on the subsequent reports. The process outlined in this document is provided as a safety net to supplement the responsibilities of the referring clinician and not to be used as a substitute for reviewing all results in a timely manner.
Definitions

table_items.text: Where emergency action is required as soon as possible or medical evaluation is required within 24 hours
Where the reporting radiologist, or reporting practitioner, has identified findings that are both significant and unexpected.

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust
Chief Executive is designated by the Trust Board as the officer with overall responsibility for Health and Safety.
Quality Governance Group will analyse and set the strategy for handling all aspects of clinical risk threatening patient safety within the Trust and other patient safety issues.

Health and Safety Group will be a proactive force in promoting the highest standards of health and safety. Any trends reported via Datix pertaining to this policy will be fed back via the MSE Radiology Governance Board
MSE Radiology Governance Board will ensure the policy is in place
Referrers:
Referrers should read and act upon the results of every investigation they request.
Referrers should ensure an accurate bleep / extension number is on the referral so that any critical / significant findings can be informed.

The clinical teams should have a robust mechanism for handover of urgent imaging reports, and for handover of pending urgent imaging study requests, to ensure that all significant imaging findings are acted upon by the clinical team in a timely manner, regardless of which clinical staff are actually on duty.
Referrers should have a clear understanding of the locally agreed fail-safe alert policy within the Trust and act upon ALL reports in a timely manner.
Reporters:
Reporters should ensure that the reports are timely, clear and precise, and the urgency for action is clearly documented within the content of the report.
Reporters should clearly document advice on further management or action, where appropriate.
Reporters should have a clear understanding of agreed local policies and workflow processes for fail-safe alert communication.
Reporters should flag / alert a report which is significant but unexpected according to site-specific processes
Reporters should verbally communicate (by telephone) to the appropriate referring team for all time critical findings which are deemed acute life or limb threatening.
Overview of the communication of time critical/significant
unexpected findings during diagnostic imaging reporting procedure
Time Critical Findings:
Where urgent treatment may be required; these are typically life or limb threatening findings.

The reporter, having identified pathology that may require urgent treatment, will ensure contact is made with the referring clinician. Out of hours or if unable to contact referring clinician, then contact should be made with the medical or surgical registrar on-call. They will provide a verbal overview of the findings indicating that a formal written report will follow; contact should be made either in person or by phone. A record of this communication must be included either within the formal report or on the RIS note pad facility / cloud to include who was spoken to and the time and date. This report should also be alert / ‘red flagged' / marked as critical.
Examples of time critical findings include:
Acute ruptured AAA which is actively bleeding.
Acute spinal cord compression which is new.
Please note this list is not exhaustive.
Note the processes for alert / ‘red flagging' a report are different for each area within each hospital site and these can be found in appendices 2-6
Significant Unexpected findings

Where medical evaluation is required within 24 hours (urgent findings) or significant unexpected findings have been identified (cases where the reporting radiologist has concerns that the findings are significant for the patient and will be unexpected by the referrer), the report should be alerted / ‘red flagged' / marked as significant and unexpected (according to site-specific processes).
Examples of Significant Unexpected Findings Include:
Evidence of malignancy in a patient without a known or suspected cancer diagnosis.
Please note this list is not exhaustive.
Note the processes for alert / ‘red flagging' a report are different for each area within each hospital site and these can be found in appendices 2-6
Significant but Expected Findings
Radiological findings may be of clinical significance, but expected within the clinical context. In this scenario a report may be issued without any additional ‘red' alert notification.
A separate pathway exists for newly detected lung cancers - as detailed in appendices 2-6 - there are different pathways for each site.
Examples of significant but expected findings include:
Progressive malignancy in a patient with a known cancer diagnosis.
Arterial occlusion/stenosis in a patient with known peripheral vascular disease.
Please note this list is not exhaustive.
Note the processes for alert / ‘red flagging' a report are different for each area within each hospital site and these can be found in appendices 1-5
Unexpected but insignificant findings
Similarly, radiological findings may be unexpected but of unlikely clinical significance. In this scenario a report may be issued without any additional ‘red' alert notification.
Examples of unexpected but less significant findings include:
Small lung/adrenal nodules.
Kidney/liver cysts.
Old fractures.
Degenerative spinal disease.
Gallstones.
Small aneurysms.
Please note this list is not exhaustive.
Training requirements
This policy applies to clinical staff that act as reporters or referrers for radiology examinations. Staff should be made aware of this policy at the point of Trust induction.
All staff would be expected to review documentation related to their role in line with their continued professional development.
Monitoring and audit
Outlined below is the Trust's process of monitoring compliance with, and the effectiveness of the document's main points.

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the MSE Radiology Governance Board, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local Radiology guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the MSE Radiology Governance Board of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.

data.text: Appendix 4: Southend Site: processes for actioning alerts raised in RIS in relation to urgent or significant unexpected findings
General Alert process:
If a reporting practitioner identifies a study which should be highlighted to the requesting clinician urgently, they should use the alert flag(s) within the RIS on the reporting tab.

The reporter will attach the flag ‘fax to requesting Consultant urgently' which will place the study on the alert list for the Clerical PACS admin team to e-fax appropriately. If the study should be highlighted to the Heart and Chest clinic then follow the process below ‘Alert email process for Chest related imaging only'
Once on the Alert list, clerical PACS admin will identify the requesting Consultant and e- fax or email the report from within our RIS to the clinic or secretary.
Inpatient cases are faxed to the consultant's secretary and the requesting ward.
After faxing the report, clerical admin will sign the study off the list by clicking the ‘delete' button to signify that the report has been highlighted to the requesting Consultant.
Lastly, clerical PACS admin will document, by copying and pasting, the alert entry onto the alert log spread-sheet (found on the x-ray departmental shared drive).
Alert email process for Chest related imaging only:

For reports that need highlighting to the chest consultants urgently, the reporter will tick the ‘ccDP' box. This triggers an automatic alert email to be sent to the ‘alert.chest' email account in Heart & Chest department. The original referrer will also be informed by following the ‘General Alert' process above.
Attendances for multiple x-ray examinations which include a chest x-ray

If there is an attendance that includes a chest x-ray (e.g. chest x-ray and abdomen x-ray) and the alert is for the non-chest attendance (i.e. in this case, the abdomen) then you need to remove the CCDP flag as the study is not relevant to the chest clinic. You just want to have the case flagged to the referring clinician. To do this, click edit alerts /flags (next to the alert CCDP check box).

data.text: Emergency Dept (ED) alert

For all ED referrals made under an ED consultant there is an “Alert ED” box available which is used to expedite an urgent or significant finding. When this alert is selected an email is automatically sent to an ED Consultant group email account. This account is regularly monitored by the ED PAs to ensure any findings are swiftly reviewed and acted upon.

data.text: Process for referral of out-patients to Emergency Dept (plain film)

If the radiographer/assistant practitioner identifies a fracture or pathology that requires attention, this should be discussed with the ‘red top' consultant in ED prior to sending the patient to ED. Initial clarification of pathology can be discussed with a reporting radiographer or radiologist.
If the ED consultant is in agreement, the patient can be walked round/directed to ED reception where they will be booked in.

As a general rule for GP patients, we should not be referring patients with un-displaced extra-articular finger/toe fractures or other non-acute fractures that can wait 24-48 hours for the GP to follow up.
Urgent/Unexpected findings on out-patient CT/MRI examinations

In the event that the radiographer identifies an urgent or unexpected finding on an out- patient CT or MRI scan, this should initially be escalated to the radiologist responsible for reporting the examination. The radiologist can offer advice as to whether the patient requires further imaging or discussion with the referring team/ED.
Alert process for Urgent / Unexpected findings: Everlight outsourced reporting

If an Everlight reporting radiologist identifies a study which contains a critical finding, they must phone and speak to the referring clinician (if available) and, failing that, should speak to the medical or surgical registrar on call (as applicable).
If an Everlight reporting radiologist identifies a study which contains a significant unexpected finding, they must email the Southend hospital distribution list.

The relevant radiologist (Dr Mo or Dr Ramavathu) on this list will review the alert, tick the ‘alert box' on the radiology information system and add a comment to the notepad on the RIS to explain what has happened. They will then email the rest of the distribution list that this has been done (to avoid duplication of work).

As per Southend reported studies, the application of this flag will place the study on the electronic work list for the Clerical PACS admin team to identify the requesting Consultant and e-fax / email the report from within the RIS to the clinic or secretary as applicable.
Inpatient cases are e-faxed / emailed to the Consultant's secretary and the requesting ward.
Lastly, Clerical PACS admin will document, by copying and pasting, the alert entry onto the alert log spread-sheet (found on the x-ray departmental shared drive).
Escalation / Urgent / Unexpected findings – Sonographers General ultrasound scans - abnormal findings

A second opinion can be requested from a Radiologist to discuss pathological findings if the Sonographer is unsure of any pathological findings. If malignancy is suspected, then the report must be flagged for referral back as urgent to the requesting clinician.
Gynae scans - suspicious masses

If a suspicious mass (suspected malignancy) is found by a Sonographer on a GP referral, the request should be referred back to the GP as urgent with a recommendation of a 2WW referral to a consultant.
To help the Gynae-Oncologists calculate RMI the Sonographer needs to include a U Score when reporting suspicious masses (we do not need to calculate RMI)
A simple cyst is not a suspicious mass and does not require a U score. Ultrasound Score (U)
1 point for each of the following; multilocular cysts, solid areas, ascites, bilateral lesions, metastases.
U= 0 (ultrasound score of 0)
U = 1 (ultrasound score of 1) U = 3 (ultrasound score of 2-5)
The U Score should be included within the conclusion of the report. Abnormal findings in obstetrics.
When an abnormality is found on a scan a referral needs to be completed for Fetal Medicine Team to review.

Appendix 6: Basildon Site: processes for actioning alerts raised in RIS in relation to urgent or significant unexpected findings
Introduction:

As part of this safety net system the reporting practitioner will add “[ALERT]” followed by the alert level at the end of the report where there is a critical, urgent or significant unexpected finding. Each day a member of the PACS team will run a daily report to extract [ALERT] reports and send an email to the referring clinicians highlighting the finding.
DEFINITION OF CRITICAL/ URGENT/SIGNIFICANT AND UNEXPECTED

The definitions described here are those suggested by the Royal College of Radiologists. In the final instance it will be a matter of clinical judgement by the reporting radiologist if the subsequent report requires urgent attention.
Critical Findings: Where emergency action is required as soon as possible
Urgent Findings: Where medical evaluation is required within  hours
Significant unexpected findings: Cases where the reporting radiologist has concerns that
the findings are significant for the patient and will be unexpected For each of these the report is run in the same way:
A report in the Radcentre statistics module has been written to pick up all reports with the word ALERT. This report is extracted to a .csv file.

Once extracted, the data in the.csv file is copied in to an Excel template called Alerts Template. The template contains a macro written to format the data in to a standard text to be copied in to an email template. An example of this is below:
“Dear Dr ,
Please be advised that the following examination has been designated an [ALERT] BTUH No: D*******
Exam: MRI Head, MRI Pituitary with contrast
Formal acknowledgement of safe receipt of this email is required.
Many thanks”
The Excel template also contains a look up table which contains the email addresses of the consultants and their Secretaries\specialty pods.

Each report is copied and pasted in to a standard Alert email template, which asks for a read receipt for audit purposes, and sent to the referrer and their secretary\specialty pod. A note is also added to the patients' attendance record in Radcentre stating that the email was sent, by whom and the date.

Once all of these emails have been sent to the relevant teams, the list is saved and stored in the _Alerts folder which is situate in the PACS department folder, with the date that the report was run.
GP Chest X-ray referrals (GPCXCA)
The Alert process is run in the same way as the Critical\Urgent\Significant and Unexpected findings. The difference is that instead of ALERT, the text GPCXCA is added to the report.
These reports are sent back to the referring GP and a copy is sent to Dr Yung and the Respiratory pod, and the imaging CT booking team to book the patient for a CT Chest.
Urgent/Unexpected findings on out-patient CT/MRI examinations

In the event that the radiographer identifies an urgent or unexpected finding on an out- patient CT or MRI scan, this should be escalated to the PACS team to ensure that it is allocated urgently for reporting.
Alert process for Urgent / Unexpected findings: Everlight outsourced reporting

If an Everlight reporting radiologist identifies a study which contains a critical finding, they must phone and speak to the referring clinician (if available) and, failing that, should speak to the medical or surgical registrar on call (as applicable).

If an Everlight reporting radiologist identifies a study which contains a significant unexpected finding, they must email the Basildon hospital distribution list (PACS Team). The PACS team will ensure that the report is sent on to the referring clinician and their Secretary\specialty pod.
